Organization.name: Environmental Management and Planning Solutions Inc
Organization.fullName: Environmental Management and Planning Solutions, Inc.

Project.summary: Panoche Valley Solar, LLC (the applicant) is proposing to construct the Panoche Valley Solar Facility, a 247 megawatt photovoltaic solar generating facility in eastern unincorporated San Benito County, California. The proposed project site contains ephemeral drainages that have been determined to be jurisdictional waters of the U.S. Construction of the proposed project requires a Department of the Army permit from the US Army Corps of Engineers to discharge fill material into these waters, in accordance with Section 404 of the Clean Water Act. The US Army Corps of Engineers, as the lead agency responsible for complying with the National Environmental Policy Act, made a preliminary determination that the proposed project constitutes a major federal action that may result in significant impacts on the environment, and that the preparation of an environmental impact statement was required. The proposed facility would consist of a solar field of ground-mounted photovoltaic modules; an electrical collection system that converts generated power from direct current to alternating current and delivers it to a project substation; and a project substation that collects and converts the generated power from 34.5 to 230 kilovolts. The electricity would then be delivered, via a new on-site Pacific Gas and Electric Company switching station, to its existing Moss Landing-Panoche 230 kilovolt transmission line. Generated electricity would be sold to Southern California Edison under a long-term power purchase agreement.

Comments.content: The Draft EIS was distributed for public review and comment from September 11, 2015 to October 26, 2015. On October 6, 2015 and October 7, 2015, the USACE held public meetings on the Draft EIS. This Final EIS responds to the substantive comments received on the Draft EIS during the public review and comment period.

Project.summary: Executive Summary

The USACE’s proposed action is to make a permit decision on the permit application submitted by Panoche Valley Solar, LLC to construct the Panoche Valley Solar Facility in eastern San Benito County, California.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: Panoche Valley Solar, LLC (the applicant) is proposing to construct the Panoche Valley Solar Facility, a photovoltaic (PV) generating facility in eastern unincorporated San Benito County, California. The proposed project site contains drainages that have been determined to be jurisdictional waters of the U.S. Construction of the proposed project requires a Department of the Army permit from the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) to discharge fill material into these waters, in accordance with Section 404 of the Clean Water Act.

The overall project purpose is to construct an approximately 247 MWAC solar PV energy generating facility and associated transmission and support facilities in the west-central portion of California’s Central Valley (generally encompassing portions of San Benito, Merced, Madera, Fresno, and Kings Counties).

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The USACE is evaluating the applicant’s proposal for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility. The alternatives analysis includes consideration of on-site and off-site configurations, as well as no action alternatives.

Organization.name: USACE

Organization.name: CDFW

Project.summary: The proposed solar facility would consist of a solar field of ground-mounted PV modules, an underground electrical collection system that converts generated power from direct current to alternating current, a project substation that collects and converts the alternating current from 34.5 kilovolts to 230 kilovolts, and a switching station that delivers the generated power to the state electrical grid.

The applicant is proposing to construct an approximately 247 MW PV generating facility on 2,5062,154 acres (project footprint). The project footprint is in unincorporated eastern San Benito County, California, approximately 30 miles south of Los Banos and 60 miles west of Fresno. The site is 2 miles from the Fresno County line and 15 miles west of Interstate 5 and the San Joaquin Valley. The solar facility and all associated land would be on property that is controlled by the applicant.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The project involves the construction of a 247 MW solar facility within a 2,506-acre project footprint. There are two no action alternatives: no build, where the solar facility would not be developed, and no USACE permit, where the facility would be constructed in a manner that avoids waters of the U.S. and does not require a USACE permit.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The applicant and Southern California Edison executed a power purchase agreement in August 2014. Southern California Edison will purchase 247 MWAC of power annually for 20 years starting in 2019. PG&E will make telecommunication upgrades to interconnect the project with the PG&E Moss Landing-Panoche 230 kV transmission line.

The applicant's proposed projectpreferred alternative involves constructing emergency egress and access roads that cross Panoche Creek, Las Aguilas Creek, and three unnamed ephemeral drainages on the eastern side of the project footprint. The project includes discharging fill material into jurisdictional ephemeral stream channels and waters of the U.S., with measures to avoid, minimize, and compensate for impacts. Alternative B also involves similar constructions with slight variations in the crossings and discharge areas.
Alternative C involves the construction of a 247 MW photovoltaic solar facility within the Westlands Competitive Renewable Energy Zone (CREZ) in Fresno and Kings Counties.

Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

projectMetadata.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
projectMetadata.location: Panoche Valley, San Benito County, California

Project.summary: The applicant has applied for a Department of the Army Section 404 permit from the USACE to allow the discharge of fill into 0.1220.121 acre of ephemeral stream channels classified as waters of the U.S. The areas affected are Panoche Creek and Las Aguilas Creek on the western side of the project footprint and three unnamed drainages on the eastern side of the project footprint. The Draft EIS for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project was published on September 11, 2015. Changes to the Final EIS text are indicated by underlining for new text and strikethrough for deleted text. The primary revisions include reductions in the proposed project footprint (and associated reductions in project impacts) and increases in the acreage of conservation lands under the applicant’s preferred alternative (Alternative A). Removal of the Panoche Creek bridge crossing resulting from further discussion with the Hollister Fire Department. Changes in affected environment information provided through public comment. Changes in the environmental impact analysis resulting from public comment or from the changes described in the bullets above. Minor editorial revisions.

Organization.name: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The applicant is proposing to conserve all lands in the project site outside of the project footprint to maintain and enhance habitat conditions for federal and state listed species. Approximately 2,514 acres interspersed throughout and next to the project footprint would be left undisturbed and designated as Valley Floor Conservation Lands. Another 442 acres of On-Site Conservation Lands contiguous with the project footprint would also be placed into conservation. Additionally, the applicant is proposing to permanently preserve and manage two large ranches: the Valadeao Ranch Conservation Lands (10,772 acres) and the Silver Creek Ranch Conservation Lands (10,890 acres). These ranchlands are contiguous with the project footprint and each other. Conservation lands are being proposed as mitigation to offset potential impacts on listed species from constructing and operating the proposed solar facility. The applicant is also proposing to provide permanent protection and management of at least 1,000 acres of Additional Conservation Lands within the Panoche Valley, approved in advance by CDFW, as high-quality, in-kind habitat for giant kangaroo rat. The total proposed conservation area is 25,618 acres. The current project output is approximately 339 megawatts of direct-current (MWDC) power, or 247 megawatts of alternating current (MWAC) power. Power from the project would be delivered via the Pacific Gas & Electric Company (PG&E) Moss Landing-Panoche 230 kilovolt (kV) transmission line.
Project.capacity: 339 megawatts of direct-current (MWDC) power, or 247 megawatts of alternating current (MWAC) power

Comments.content: Most of the scoping comments focused on biological issues, especially impacts on sensitive and protected species, migratory birds, and grassland ecosystems.

The EPA and other commenters requested an estimation of the quantity of water required during construction and operation, the proposed source of the water, a description of water rights permitting and the status of water rights in the basin, the potential impact on other water users in the area, and the potential impacts on surface and groundwater.

The EPA indicated that the EIS should include a robust discussion of alternatives, including alternative sites, capacities, and technologies, and that an environmentally preferable alternative be identified.
A number of individuals had concerns over the impact the facility would have on the value of their property, local businesses, tourism, Panoche schoolchildren, and the community.

Project.summary: In the Federal Register on July 19, 2012 (Fed. Reg. Vol. 77, No. 139, p. 42488), the USACE initiated a 30-day scoping period for this EIS; this period was extended by nearly 20 days to end on September 7, 2012. The NOI was published in the Hollister Free Lance on July 31 and August 3, 2012. Also, it was mailed to federal, state, and local agencies, organizations, and individuals known to have an interest in the project. The NOI invited the public to provide information on environmental impacts that could occur as a result of the proposed project as proposed in 2012. Copies of these materials are in Appendix A of this EIS. Public scoping meetings were held on August 21, 2012, at the Panoche School in Paicines, California, and on August 22, 2012, at the Veterans Memorial Building in Hollister, California. The meetings began with an open house that served as an informal question and answer session, followed by a formal presentation and oral comments. Eleven people attended the scoping meeting in Paicines, and six entered comments into the public record; thirty people attended the scoping meeting in Hollister, and nine entered comments into the public record. A court reporter recorded the formal presentations and oral comments to accurately capture the information presented at the meetings. The scoping period ended on September 7, 2012. Twenty written comment letters were submitted by the following agencies, tribes, and organizations and by 12 individuals (in all, 21 individuals commented with either written or oral comments).

Organization.name: Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians
Citizens Committee to Complete the Refuge

Project.summary: The EPA and various commenters expressed concerns over public health and safety, hazardous materials, noise, air quality, cumulative impacts, project description and design, and fire risks associated with the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project.

Comments.content: The EPA requested that the EIS identify hazardous waste types and volumes, applicability of state and federal hazardous waste requirements, and mitigations that include minimizing generation of hazardous waste.

Commenters expressed concern about naturally occurring arsenic, pesticide residue, and potential for valley fever from construction-generated dust. Some expressed concern over potential soil and water contamination from the project.
Commenters requested that the EIS address impacts on emergency service providers and waste disposal at the end of solar panel life.

Individual commenters expressed concerns over the levels and duration of construction-related noise, including that from post installation and traffic, the change in background noise levels in a rural environment, impacts on Panoche schoolchildren, and impacts on livestock and domestic and wild animals. One commenter requested that the EIS evaluate operational noise levels.

The EPA requested that the EIS estimate construction and operational air emissions, identify measures to minimize emissions, and include a draft construction emissions mitigation plan. A number of individual commenters expressed concerns over construction-related impacts on air quality, primarily fugitive dust impacts from soil disturbance.

The EPA requested an in-depth cumulative impacts analysis, including identification of cumulative projects, geographic area, and temporal boundaries; current conditions, trends, and future conditions; parties responsible for minimizing impacts; and opportunities to minimize impacts. The agency also requested that the EIS evaluate impacts from the additional power supply and cumulative impacts associated with the transmission needs of other reasonably foreseeable projects.

Commenters requested that the EIS analyze cumulative impacts on sensitive species from solar development in the region. Some commenters requested the EIS analyze cumulative impacts on waters of the U.S. and on species that depend on those waters.

Several commenters requested details on the applicant’s proposed project, made suggestions about the design and implementation of the project, or provided opinions on solar technology. Commenters requested that information on interconnection and transmission be included in the EIS, including requirements for upgrades. One commenter requested an accounting of acreage required for roads and conduit.
Some commenters suggested the use of a more efficient photovoltaic panel to reduce the project footprint.

Commenters requested that the EIS analyze the potential fire risks from the proposed project and measures that would be taken to minimize this risk. Individuals expressed concern that the project would increase the risk of fire and expressed concern over firefighter response times.

Project.summary: The EPA and other commenters provided feedback on the EIS regarding various issues such as impact analysis, land use, environmental justice, soils and geology, and the Section 404 permitting process. The USACE submitted the Draft EIS to the EPA, and public notices were issued to inform and solicit comments from the public.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Comments.content: The EPA requested that the EIS clearly describe the rationale used to determine whether impacts of an alternative are significant.
One organization described elements to be considered when evaluating the intensity of an impact.

The EPA requested that the EIS describe the current condition of the land, if it is disturbed, and to what extent the land could be used for other purposes. It also requested that the EIS discuss how the project would support or conflict with the objectives of federal, state, tribal, or local land use plans and policies.
One commenter requested that the EIS evaluate impacts on recreationists, particularly bird watchers.
The EPA requested an evaluation of environmental justice populations within the geographic scope of the project and the potential for disproportionate impacts on these populations.
One commenter expressed concern over access to information by the Hispanic community.
One commenter requested that the EIS analyze impacts from the project on Class I soils. Another commenter expressed concern over soil erosion.
Two commenters asked that comments provided to the USACE through the Section 404 public noticing process be included and addressed in the EIS.

Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility Final EIS addresses various scoping issues including cultural resources, traffic and transportation, purpose and need, general mitigation, agriculture, visual resources, climate change, and decommissioning.

Organization.name: Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians

Comments.content: The EPA requested that the EIS describe the process and outcome of government-to-government consultation with tribal governments, address the existence of sacred sites in the area, and provide a summary of coordination with tribes and the state historic preservation office (SHPO), including identification of sites eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP) and development of a cultural resource management plan.

The Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians expressed concerns that the proposed project would negatively affect sacred lands and damage resources with ecological and cultural significance. The tribe expressed specific concerns on impacts on subsurface resources and requested that the applicant hire a tribal representative to monitor all ground disturbance activities, including the removal, repair, or replacement of any solar panel pole.
Individual commenters expressed concerns about construction-related traffic on area roadways, specifically the volume of traffic, hazardous road conditions, and degradation of already poor roads.

The EPA indicated that the EIS should include a strong rationale for the proposed project. The agency, along with several other commenters, requested identification of power purchasers and how the proposed project would help meet California’s renewable portfolio standards.

The EPA requested that the EIS adopt a formal adaptive management plan. Other commenters expressed concern that the project lacks a suitable restoration plan. Commenters requested that lands be identified to fully mitigate project impacts and that deferred mitigation not be allowed, that the EIS analyze the impacts of the mitigations imposed by the EIR, and that funding assurances and an enforceable schedule for restoration be included.

Individual commenters expressed concerns about impacts the project would have on local agriculture. They requested that the EIS evaluate impacts on local farmers, impacts from loss of grazing, and impacts on soils from solar panels. One commenter also stated that the valley was not farmed because of property owner choice, not because of irrigation inefficiencies or poor water quality.
Commenters expressed concern over impacts on the visual character of the area in general and impacts from light pollution on the night sky specifically.

The EPA requested that the EIS evaluate how water reliability might be affected by climate change, how climate change could influence the project, and how impacts from the project might be exacerbated by climate change. The agency also requested that the EIS quantify and disclose potential benefits on climate change from solar energy and quantify greenhouse gas emissions from different types of generating facilities. One organization requested that the EIS address the effects of global climate change on plants, animals, and habitats in the Panoche Valley as part of the future environmental baseline.

Individual commenters requested more information and commitment on the decommissioning of the proposed project, including setting aside funds for restoration. One commenter expressed the opinion that the facility not be decommissioned after 30 years but that the technology be updated.

Project.summary: The page provides a summary of the potential environmental effects that could result from implementing the no action (no build) alternative, the no action (no USACE permit) alternative, and Alternatives A, B, and C for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility. The on-site alternatives evaluated in the EIS incorporate applicant-proposed measures, EIR mitigation measures, and PG&E avoidance and minimization measures to avoid and reduce impacts resulting from construction and operation of the proposed solar facility.

Project.summary: The document provides an executive summary of the Panoche Valley Solar Facility's Final Environmental Impact Statement (EIS). It discusses the environmental impacts of various alternatives, including the No Action alternative, Alternative A (Applicant’s Proposed Project), Alternative B (On-site Alternative), and Alternative C (Off-site Alternative, Westlands CREZ). The impacts on aesthetics, dust generation, lighting, and the construction of new microwave equipment are considered less than significant.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The document discusses various alternatives for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project and their impacts on agricultural resources. The no action alternative would result in no construction and continuation of current agricultural uses. Other alternatives involve converting grazing land to solar development with measures to offset the loss of agricultural land through conservation easements.

During the public review period, interested parties were invited to comment on the Draft EIS through submission of written and verbal comments. The 45-day public review period for the Draft EIS ran from September 11, 2015 to October 26, 2015. Two public meetings on the Draft EIS were held in the project area. The first meeting was held on October 6, 2015, at the Veterans Memorial Building in Hollister, California. The second meeting was held on October 7, 2015, at the Panoche Elementary School in Paicines, California. The meetings were conducted in an open house format. Informational posters and a PowerPoint presentation provided information on the proposed project evaluated in the Draft EIS, the NEPA process, and the USACE regulatory program. Representatives from the USACE, the project applicant, and the EIS preparer were available to answer questions. A court reporter was present at the meetings to enter verbal comments into the public record. Twenty-eight people attended the public meeting on October 6, 2015, and nineteen individuals entered verbal comments into the public record. Fifteen people attended the public meeting on October 7, 2015, and no attendees entered verbal comments into the public record. No tribal, federal or state agency, or organizational representatives attended or provided comments at either meeting. Comment letters were submitted by various agencies and organizations; seven individuals also submitted comments.

It involves telecommunication upgrades by PG&E that produce minor greenhouse gases and has cumulative impacts that are less than significant. The project supports California's Renewable Portfolio Standard and the California Global Warming Solutions Act.

Project.summary: The nature and type of effects from operational and maintenance activities would be similar to those described for construction. Permanent disturbance resulting from construction of PG&E primary telecommunication upgrades would be limited. Preparation of the temporary pull/splice sites, helicopter landing zones, and work areas for the new permanent wood poles would require some minor ground disturbance, including vegetation trimming, recontouring, and lightly compacting the ground. Because PG&E has proposed as part of the no action (no permit) alternative to implement BMPs and revegetation measures to reduce any temporary effects on soil and vegetation, direct and indirect impacts would be less than significant. Cumulative impacts would be less than significant.

Project.summary: The no action (no permit) alternative would have indirect impacts on the historic landscape setting, altering the landscape by imposing modern industrial features in the rural viewshed. As the Panoche Valley has not been recommended or identified as a rural historic landscape, and many of its component parts lack integrity, the alterations in the landscape setting would not result in an adverse effect under the NHPA or a significant impact under NEPA. Proposed project operations would not encounter unanticipated resources due to the lack of surface-disturbing actions. However, if such discoveries were made, the measures included as part of the no action (no permit) alternative would reduce the potential for adversely affecting previously undiscovered cultural artifacts or human remains. With implementation of these measures, operational-related impacts would be less than significant and would not constitute an adverse effect under the NHPA or a significant effect under NEPA. All identified cultural resources near telecommunication upgrade sites would be outside of the PG&E work areas or would be avoided. Therefore, there would be no direct effects on any of the identified cultural resources.

Project.summary: The document outlines the socio-economic impacts of various alternatives for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project, including no action, applicant's proposed project, on-site alternative, and off-site alternative.

The presence of the solar infrastructure would have a long-term less than significant indirect impact on scattered rural residences, recreationists en-route to BLM-administered lands, and other travelers through the Panoche Valley by altering the rural and agricultural character of the immediate project area. Creating permanent conservation easements on the 10,772-acre Valadeao Ranch and 10,890-acre Silver Creek Ranch would ensure that the open space value and rural character of these lands are preserved in perpetuity. Operational and maintenance activities for the solar facility are allowable activities and would not conflict with any local plans or regulations. These activities would not divide a community or disrupt uses on surrounding lands. Impacts would be less than significant.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

It addresses impacts on public health, safety, and minority populations, as well as required mitigation measures.

Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The project involves the construction and operation of a solar facility in the Panoche Valley. The full-time operational and maintenance staff would consist of up to 50 people. The project aims to provide economic benefits to local governments through tax revenues during operation. Environmental justice impacts are considered less than significant.

The document discusses various alternatives for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project, including No Action, Alternative A (Applicant’s Proposed Project), Alternative B (On-site Alternative), and Alternative C (Off-site Alternative, Westlands CREZ). It describes measures to mitigate public health and safety impacts, including training personnel in hazardous materials handling and maintaining a Spill Prevention, Control, and Countermeasure Plan. The project also includes 24-hour on-site security to prevent vandalism.

Project.summary: Executive Summary: The document outlines the environmental impacts of the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project under various alternatives, including no action, alternative A (applicant's proposed project), alternative B (on-site alternative), and alternative C (off-site alternative, Westlands CREZ). Noise impacts from operational and maintenance activities, construction equipment, and telecommunication upgrades are discussed, with all impacts deemed less than significant.

It highlights the potential impacts on emergency vehicle operations, roadway conditions, and traffic.

It highlights that traffic disruptions during construction would be minimized via a traffic control plan and that long-term impacts on transportation would be less than significant.

Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility is a photovoltaic (PV) generating facility proposed by Panoche Valley Solar, LLC in eastern unincorporated San Benito County, California. The project requires a Department of the Army permit from the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) to discharge fill material into jurisdictional waters in accordance with Section 404 of the Clean Water Act. The USACE determined that an environmental impact statement (EIS) was required under NEPA due to significant potential environmental impacts.

projectMetadata.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
projectMetadata.location: eastern San Benito County and western Fresno County

Project.summary: The applicant's preferred alternative involves constructing a 247 MW solar facility on approximately 2,154 acres and permanently preserving and managing 25,618 acres of conservation lands.

The proposed solar facility includes a solar field of ground-mounted PV modules, an underground electrical collection system, a project substation, and a switching station. The applicant is also proposing to conserve lands within the project site, including Valley Floor Conservation Lands and additional conservation lands to offset potential impacts on listed species.

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The applicant is proposing to construct an approximately 247 megawatt (MW) PV generating facility on 2,154 acres. The project output is approximately 339 megawatts of direct-current (MWDC) power, or 247 megawatts of alternating current (MWAC) power. Power from the project would be delivered via the Pacific Gas & Electric Company (PG&E) Moss Landing-Panoche 230 kilovolt (kV) transmission line.

Organization.name: California Department of Fish and Wildlife
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The project involves construction activities impacting ephemeral stream channels, including the placement of fill material and construction of bridge crossings at Las Aguilas and Panoche Creeks. Measures to avoid, minimize, or compensate for impacts on waters of the U.S. are outlined.

The applicant has revised the application to further avoid and minimize impacts on waters of the U.S. by reducing road crossings and eliminating impacts from burying utility lines. Changes include reducing bridge crossings, avoiding giant kangaroo habitat, and converting temporary impact areas into conservation lands.

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project involves developing a solar energy project in Panoche Valley. The project initially proposed a 1,000 MWAC PV solar energy project on approximately 10,000 acres, which was later reduced to 420 MWAC on approximately 4,700 acres due to environmental concerns. Further reductions brought the project down to 399 MWAC to avoid biologically sensitive areas.

Project.summary: San Benito County prepared a supplemental EIR to evaluate changes to the project since the EIR was certified in 2010. The applicant incorporated additional giant kangaroo rat avoidance areas, blunt-nosed leopard lizard avoidance buffers, and a San Joaquin kit fox travel/dispersal corridor. The USACE, San Francisco District determined that the proposed project may have more than minimal adverse impacts on the environment and required an individual permit.

Project.summary: The focus of the environmental analysis for each alternative includes the direct and indirect effects of constructing a solar facility. This includes short-term effects from construction activities and long-term effects from the presence of a solar facility. It also includes the effects from operational and maintenance activities associated with operating the facility, which are considered an indirect effect of the construction of the solar facility.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project involves the construction of a solar energy facility. The project includes various alternatives, each with different environmental impacts. The No Action Alternative would maintain current land uses and public health conditions without any telecommunication upgrades. Alternative A, the Applicant's Proposed Project, and Alternative B, the On-site Alternative, both propose similar measures to mitigate impacts, including compliance with federal, state, and local laws regarding hazardous materials. Alternative C, the Off-site Alternative, also includes measures to minimize potential risks.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

projectMetadata.name: Panoche Valley Solar Facility
projectMetadata.location: Panoche Valley region, San Benito County, California

Project.summary: The applicant submitted a Department of the Army permit application to the USACE to construct the solar PV energy generating facility in the Panoche Valley region of San Benito County. The power generated by this project would assist the State of California and its retail suppliers of electricity to meet the mandatory Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) under California law. This law requires electricity providers to procure 33 percent of their electricity from renewable energy sources by 2020 (2011 Senate Bill SBX 1-2). The project would also assist the state to meet targeted reductions in greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by 2020 (California Global Warming Solutions Act of 2006 [Assembly Bill 32]). The applicant executed a power purchase agreement with Southern California Edison in August 2014. Under this agreement, the applicant is obligated to deliver 247 MWAC of power annually for 20 years, beginning in 2019.

The document discusses the NEPA process, public participation, and scoping for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project. It includes information on permits, authorizations, and plans required for the project.

Project.summary: The document discusses the introduction, statement of purpose, and need for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project. It also summarizes public comments and the public review process for the Draft EIS.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Comments.content: One commenter requested that the EIS analyze impacts from the project on Class I soils. Another commenter expressed concern over soil erosion.
Two commenters asked that comments provided to the USACE through the Section 404 public noticing process be included and addressed in the EIS.

The EPA and other commenters requested an estimation of the quantity of water required during construction and operation, the proposed source of the water, a description of water rights permitting and the status of water rights in the basin, the potential impact on other water users in the area, and the potential impacts on surface and groundwater. The EPA also requested an analysis of technologies that can be used to minimize or recycle water and whether it would be feasible to use other sources of water. The agency requested that the impacts on waters of the U.S. be identified and floodplains and stormwater flow be analyzed. Some commenters expressed concern over potential contaminants leaching from solar facility equipment.

The EPA indicated that the EIS should include a robust discussion of alternatives, including alternative sites, capacities, and technologies, and that an environmentally preferable alternative be identified. It requested that the EIS provide a clear discussion of the reasons for eliminating alternatives not discussed in detail, how each alternative was developed, how it addresses each project objective, and how it will be implemented. Both local commenters and nonprofit organizations asked to see alternative locations for the site, including in the Westlands Competitive Renewable Energy Zone; alternatives to utility-scale solar, including rooftop solar and smaller facilities located closer to users; and more efficient solar panels. Some commenters requested an alternative that avoided all stream crossings.

A number of individuals had concerns over the impact the facility would have on the value of their property, local businesses, tourism, Panoche schoolchildren, and the community. One commenter expressed concerns about housing impacts during construction due to the number of temporary workers. Some commenters expressed support of the project for the potential economic benefits it could have on the regional economy.

The EPA requested that the EIS identify hazardous waste types and volumes, applicability of state and federal hazardous waste requirements, and mitigations that include minimizing generation of hazardous waste. Commenters expressed concern about naturally occurring arsenic, pesticide residue, and potential for valley fever from construction-generated dust. Some expressed concern over potential soil and water contamination from the project. Commenters requested that the EIS address impacts on emergency service providers and waste disposal at the end of solar panel life.

Individual commenters expressed concerns over the levels and duration of construction-related noise, including that from post installation and traffic, the change in background noise levels in a rural environment, impacts on Panoche schoolchildren, and impacts on livestock and domestic and wild animals. One commenter requested that the EIS evaluate operational noise levels.

Project.summary: The document discusses various scoping issues related to the Panoche Valley Solar Facility, including air quality, cumulative impacts, project description and design, fire risks, cultural resources, and traffic and transportation.

Organization.name: The Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan Ohlone Indians
Organization.fullName: The Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians

Comments.content: The EPA requested that the EIS estimate construction and operational air emissions, identify measures to minimize emissions, and include a draft construction emissions mitigation plan. A number of individual commenters expressed concerns over construction-related impacts on air quality, primarily fugitive dust impacts from soil disturbance.

The EPA requested an in-depth cumulative impacts analysis, including identification of cumulative projects, geographic area, and temporal boundaries; current conditions, trends, and future conditions; parties responsible for minimizing impacts; and opportunities to minimize impacts. The agency also requested that the EIS evaluate impacts from the additional power supply and cumulative impacts associated with the transmission needs of other reasonably foreseeable projects. Commenters requested that the EIS analyze cumulative impacts on sensitive species from solar development in the region. Some commenters requested the EIS analyze cumulative impacts on water supplies, on waters of the U.S., and on species that depend on those waters.

Several commenters requested details on the applicant’s proposed project, made suggestions about the design and implementation of the project, or provided opinions on solar technology. Commenters requested that information on interconnection and transmission be included in the EIS, including requirements for upgrades. One commenter requested an accounting of acreage required for roads and conduit. Some commenters suggested the use of a more efficient photovoltaic panel to reduce the project footprint.

Commenters requested that the EIS analyze the potential fire risks from the proposed project and measures that would be taken to minimize this risk. Individuals expressed concern that the project would increase the risk of fire and expressed concern over firefighter response times.

The EPA requested that the EIS describe the process and outcome of government-to-government consultation with tribal governments, address the existence of sacred sites in the area, and provide a summary of coordination with tribes and the state historic preservation office (SHPO), including identification of sites eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP) and development of a cultural resource management plan. The Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians expressed concerns that the proposed project would negatively affect sacred lands and damage resources with ecological and cultural significance. The tribe expressed specific concerns on impacts on subsurface resources and requested that the applicant hire a tribal representative to monitor all ground disturbance activities, including the removal, repair, or replacement of any solar panel pole.
Individual commenters expressed concerns about construction-related traffic on area roadways, specifically the volume of traffic, hazardous road conditions, and degradation of already poor roads.

Project.summary: The scoping period ended on September 7, 2012. Twenty written comment letters were submitted by various agencies, tribes, organizations, and individuals. Most comments focused on biological resource issues, including impacts on sensitive species, migratory birds, and grassland ecosystems.

Persons.name: Valentin Lopez
Persons.role: Amah Mutsun Tribal Band of Costanoan/Ohlone Indians

Organization.name: Citizens Committee to Complete the Refuge
Organization.fullName: Citizens Committee to Complete the Refuge

Organization.name: USFWS

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Comments.content: Most of the scoping comments focused on biological issues, especially impacts on sensitive and protected species, migratory birds, and grassland ecosystems. Commenters requested a full accounting of sensitive species, a thorough analysis of project and cumulative impacts, a description of measures to avoid, minimize, and mitigate project impacts, and provisions of mitigation, monitoring, and translocation plans.

The EPA and other commenters requested an analysis of the potential for habitat fragmentation, identification and analysis of compensatory mitigation proposals, and consultation with the USFWS and CDFW to incorporate lessons learned from other renewable projects and recent guidance to avoid and minimize adverse effects on sensitive species.

Project.summary: The document discusses various scoping issues and comments related to the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project, including the need for a strong rationale, mitigation plans, impacts on agriculture, visual resources, climate change, decommissioning, impact analysis, land use and recreation, and environmental justice.

Comments.content: The EPA indicated that the EIS should include a strong rationale for the proposed project. The agency, along with several other commenters, requested identification of power purchasers and how the proposed project would help meet California’s renewable portfolio standards.

The EPA requested that the EIS adopt a formal adaptive management plan. Other commenters expressed concern that the project lacks a suitable restoration plan. Commenters requested that lands be identified to fully mitigate project impacts and that deferred mitigation not be allowed, that the EIS analyze the impacts of the mitigations imposed by the EIR, and that funding assurances and an enforceable schedule for restoration be included.

Individual commenters expressed concerns about impacts the project would have on local agriculture. They requested that the EIS evaluate impacts on local farmers, impacts from loss of grazing, and impacts on soils from solar panels. One commenter also stated that the valley was not farmed because of property owner choice, not because of irrigation inefficiencies or poor water quality.
Commenters expressed concern over impacts on the visual character of the area in general and impacts from light pollution on the night sky specifically.

The EPA requested that the EIS evaluate how water reliability might be affected by climate change, how climate change could influence the project, and how impacts from the project might be exacerbated by climate change. The agency also requested that the EIS quantify and disclose potential benefits on climate change from solar energy and quantify greenhouse gas emissions from different types of generating facilities. One organization requested that the EIS address the effects of global climate change on plants, animals, and habitats in the Panoche Valley as part of the future environmental baseline.

Individual commenters requested more information and commitment on the decommissioning of the proposed project, including setting aside funds for restoration. One commenter expressed the opinion that the facility not be decommissioned after 30 years but that the technology be updated.

The EPA requested that the EIS clearly describe the rationale used to determine whether impacts of an alternative are significant. One organization described elements to be considered when evaluating the intensity of an impact.

The EPA requested that the EIS describe the current condition of the land, if it is disturbed, and to what extent the land could be used for other purposes. It also requested that the EIS discuss how the project would support or conflict with the objectives of federal, state, tribal, or local land use plans and policies. One commenter requested that the EIS evaluate impacts on recreationists, particularly bird watchers.

The EPA requested an evaluation of environmental justice populations within the geographic scope of the project and the potential for disproportionate impacts on these populations. One commenter expressed concern over access to information by the Hispanic community.

Project.summary: The project involves the construction of a 247 MW solar facility, with alternatives including no action and no build options. The USACE is evaluating the project's compliance with Section 404(b)(1) Guidelines.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The applicant submitted a Department of the Army permit application in April 2010 for a 420 MW solar facility. The applicant submitted a revised permit application in December 2010 for a 399 MW solar facility (the project approved by San Benito County in 2010); it was estimated in this application that project impacts would include 427 cubic yards of fill into Panoche and Las Aguilas Creeks. The applicant submitted alternatives information to the USACE in November 2012 (Power Engineers 2012) and in December 2014 submitted revised alternatives information. This revised information accounted for changes in the proposed project resulting from biological survey information, interconnection requirements by PG&E, and revisions to the jurisdictional determination (Energy Renewal Partners 2014). The applicant’s current alternatives information (Energy Renewal Partners 2015b), submitted to the USACE in August December 2015, is included in Appendix B. The USACE has not reviewed this updated alternatives information but is providing it for the public to comment on. The applicant’s preferred alternative (Alternative A) described in the 2014 alternatives information included project impacts of approximately 6 cubic yards of cut and 5 cubic yards of fill in Panoche Creek, 10 11 cubic yards of cut and 10 cubic yards of fill in Las Aguilas Creek, and 22 cubic yards of cut and 646 cubic yards of fill in three unnamed ephemeral drainages in the eastern portion of the project footprint. Impacts to Panoche Creek were eliminated based on a letter from the Hollister Fire Department dated August 27, 2015, indicating that it would be acceptable to eliminate a bridge over Panoche Creek provided all other emergency access elements be retained and constructed and emergency access areas be established on the site. This would amount to a total discharge of fill material into 0.121 acre of waters of the U.S. in the project footprint. This is evaluated as Alternative A (Applicant’s Proposed Project Preferred Alternative) and is described in Section 2.5. In addition, the applicant is proposing 0.096 acre of potential impacts to waters of the U.S. associated with debris removal in two ephemeral drainages on the conservation lands proposed as compensatory mitigation for the proposed loss of waters of the U.S. associated with the applicant’s preferred alternative.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The document discusses the project description and alternatives for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility, including impacts on waters of the U.S., significant adverse environmental consequences, and an off-site alternatives analysis in compliance with the Clean Water Act Section 404(b)(1) Guidelines.

Project.summary: The proposed project involves the discharge of dredged and fill material into 0.1220.121 acre of waters of the U.S. subject to Section 404(b)(1) Guidelines. The project aims to evaluate reasonable and practicable alternatives for a solar facility in the west-central portion of the Central Valley, including parts of San Benito, Kings, Fresno, Merced, and Madera Counties. Key considerations include cost, logistics, emergency ingress and egress, and proximity to existing 230 kV transmission lines.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The project aims to meet its obligations under the executed PPA with Southern California Edison to deliver 247 MW by 2019. Various alternative sites and technologies were evaluated, but only the Westlands CREZ Alternative was carried forward for detailed analysis.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The USACE has determined that a minimum of approximately 2,000 acres is needed to develop a 247 MW solar facility. This determination was based on a review of California solar facilities in various stages of development.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The applicant would build the proposed project, but in a manner that did not require a USACE permit. The USACE has determined it is appropriate to evaluate both no action scenarios in the EIS. To differentiate between the two no action scenarios, they are referred to as the no action (no build) alternative and the no action (no permit) alternative.

The project applicant is proposing to construct the Panoche Valley Solar Facility on lands that it secured with options to purchase. The applicant’s currently proposed project would include a 2,506-acre solar facility (project footprint) and 24,176 acres of conservation lands.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The no action (no permit) alternative would avoid grading within jurisdictional areas on the eastern portion of the project site and use bottomless culverts to accommodate installation of the perimeter road. To offset the loss of developable area in the eastern portion of the project footprint, five 1.67 MWAC solar arrays would either be split into smaller blocks with less spacing between panel rows or would be relocated to avoid impacts on waters of the U.S. Relocated arrays would be moved to the western portion of the project footprint, requiring additional medium voltage switchgear and cable to be routed to the east side transformer in the project substation.

The project involves the construction and operation of the Panoche Valley Solar Facility, with conservation lands proposed as mitigation for impacts on federally and state-listed species under the Endangered Species Act. The project will also provide permanent protection and management of at least 1,000 acres of Additional Conservation Lands.

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project involves the installation of over one million PV panels on approximately 1,529 acres of the project footprint. The project includes a solar field of ground-mounted PV modules, an underground electrical collection system, a substation, and a switching station. The generated power will be delivered to the state electrical grid via PG&E’s Moss Landing-Panoche/Coburn-Panoche 230 kV transmission line.
Project.technology: PV panels with a single-axis tracker system

Organization.name: PG&E
Organization.role: Telecommunications network upgrades and transmission line provider

Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project includes the installation of high-efficiency PV panels within the same project footprint without any increase in resource impacts. The project features a 20-foot-wide perimeter road for maintenance and emergency response, interstitial space for transportation access, and various electrical components including combiner boxes, inverters, and transformers. The direct current generated by the PV panels will be converted to alternating current and transmitted to a proposed substation via 34.5 kV collection lines.

The project involves constructing a substation and switching station north of the existing PG&E transmission line on the west side of Little Panoche Road. The substation will include electrical transformers, switchgear, and related facilities to transform medium-voltage power to the existing 230 kV transmission line. Additional infrastructure includes a microwave tower, tubular steel poles, and an operations and maintenance building.

The project involves the installation of solar arrays, perimeter roads, a substation, switching station, O&M building, and other related infrastructure over a total footprint of approximately 2,506 acres. The facility consists of 145 1.67-MW power blocks and 6 0.83-MW power blocks. Rows of panels will be spaced to prevent shading and will be configured into power blocks connected to an inverter system to convert direct current to alternating current.

The project involves the construction of an O&M building for operations equipment, parts storage, security, and site monitoring. It includes the development of project roads, perimeter roads, and access roads with specific dimensions and usage restrictions. The design and implementation are subject to local codes, standards, and approvals from relevant authorities.

Organization.name: San Benito County Public Works Engineers and Administrator

Project.summary: The project involves the construction of single-span bridges over Las Aguilas and Panoche Creeks, with specific impacts on creek crossings, including cut and fill within the OHWM and upland habitat disturbance.

The project involves the construction of a 20-foot-wide perimeter road for maintenance and emergency response. It includes the installation of a pipe arch culvert at Crossing/Impact Area 3, with additional grading and filling of jurisdictional areas.

Emergency egress and access roads for the project would cross Panoche Creek, Las Aguilas Creek, and three unnamed drainages on the eastern side of the project footprint. These crossings require permits from USACE under Section 404 of the Clean Water Act and a Section 401 Water Quality Certification from the Regional Water Quality Control Board. The applicant has applied for a Department of the Army Section 404 permit from the USACE to allow the placement of fill into 0.1220.121 acre of ephemeral stream channels classified as other waters of the U.S. Under Alternative A, single-span bridges would be used to cross Las Aguilas Creek and Panoche Creek.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The project involves installing a tracker system between solar panels, grading and filling to limit the height of the modules, and installing erosion protection measures. It also includes the construction of a culvert and low water crossings to manage surface water flows.

The project involves the construction of low water crossings, grading and filling of jurisdictional areas to meet slope requirements for solar panels, and the installation of security fencing around the project footprint.

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Organization.name: USFWS
Organization.fullName: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

Project.summary: The project involves the construction of various permanent infrastructures such as perimeter roads, emergency access points, perimeter fence, maintenance transportation corridors, substation, switching station, O&M facility, tubular steel transmission poles, stormwater control basin, parking areas, collector lines, solar array footers, and equipment pads. The project includes site disturbance and grading activities within the project footprint, which total approximately 358 352 acres. Temporary impacts from construction will be restored according to the habitat restoration and revegetation plan.

The project involves the installation of various types of fencing for wildlife exclusion and safety, construction of temporary water ponds and tanks, and installation of permanent water storage tanks and piping for operational needs.

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The project involves the construction of solar arrays, perimeter roads, substation, switching station, O&M building, and other related infrastructure. The project aims to minimize grading due to the flat terrain and includes temporary and permanent disturbances.

The project includes a stormwater pollution prevention plan (SWPPP) with best management practices (BMPs) to minimize erosion and runoff, revegetation after grading, and installation of structural BMPs. Utilities during construction include electricity from the local power grid and portable generators, water from on-site wells, and portable sanitary facilities.

AT&T would route the fiber and/or copper under Little Panoche Road west using a directional bore. Once the fiber reaches the project’s manhole/splice box, the applicant would install the underground conduit for all fiber within the project footprint. Water would be required on-site during construction of the project, primarily for dust control and sanitary facilities. This water would be provided by pumping groundwater from the Panoche Valley Groundwater Basin, using existing water wells or new wells, into two temporary construction water holding ponds and tanks placed within the project footprint.

The project involves the construction of two temporary ponds with a combined capacity of approximately 4,433,000 gallons, covering about 13 acres. These ponds will be surrounded by species exclusion fencing or located in laydown areas. Up to five new water wells may be drilled if existing wells are insufficient. Peak daily and annual water demand during construction is estimated at 1.72 acre-feet (581,250 gallons) and 314.87 acre-feet (102,600,000 gallons), respectively. Total construction water usage is estimated at 385.15 acre-feet (125,500,500 gallons). A septic tank and leach field will be constructed near the O&M building, with a minimum tank size of 750 gallons, conforming to federal, state, and San Benito County requirements.

The project involves commissioning and maintenance activities, interior use of the operations and maintenance facility, handling unanticipated emergencies, special status species impact avoidance and minimization activities, and security patrols. No ground-disturbing activities would take place at night. Construction activities are permitted from sunrise to sunset, with specific site preparation and panel assembly procedures.

The project involves the construction of solar panels in a clockwise progression around the site over approximately 18 months, beginning in 2015. Emergency response plans and fire safety measures, including the use of Novec 1240 clean agent flooding system, are included.

Organization.name: San Benito County Public Health Department
Organization.fullName: San Benito County Public Health Department

Project.summary: A prefabricated racking system would arrive on-site to be assembled and grounded. Preassembled PV panels would arrive on-site and be placed in a staging area inside or on shipping containers. Panels would be put in place manually and secured to the rack according to vendor specifications. The rack would be populated with panels, wired in series, and connected to a DC combiner box, which would deliver DC power to the local inverters. Equipment used for system installation would include 4x4 forklifts, all-terrain vehicles, truck-mounted pile drivers, cranes, and pickup trucks. Approximately 108 105 acres are planned for laydown and staging. Each laydown area would be at a convenient spot for construction traffic to access from existing roads. The laydown areas would require a power source for lighting, construction trailers, and parking. There would be no hazardous substances stored on-site outside of approved containment measures.

The applicant’s proposed project has evolved over time, first through the San Benito County permitting process and CEQA analysis, and then through coordination with the USFWS and the CDFW, which resulted in the currently proposed project (identified as the applicant’s preferred alternative (Alternative A) in this Final EIS). A number of project configurations and project output capacities have been studied at the project site. During preparation of this EIS, the USACE continued to evaluate alternative site configurations to further reduce impacts on aquatic resources (fill into waters of the U.S.) and sensitive biological resources. On-site alternatives evaluated in the applicant’s 404(b)(1) alternatives information, alternative configurations and capacities suggested by agencies and the public during project scoping, and alternative configurations investigated with the USFWS and CDFW were evaluated for their ability to meet the project purpose and need. The goal in developing on-site alternative configurations was to reduce impacts likely to be associated with the project as currently proposed, with an emphasis on reducing impacts on aquatic resources (fill into waters of the U.S.). No alternative configurations were found that further minimized impacts on waters of the U.S. and sensitive biological species, while still providing a project output of 247 MW, as specified in the overall project purpose. One alternative was found that reduced aquatic impacts by avoiding placing fill into Panoche and Las Aguilas Creeks (waters of the U.S.). However, this alternative would not provide for adequate emergency access to the site required by the Hollister Fire Chief (Hollister Fire Department 2014, 2015), so it was not evaluated in detail. The alternative configurations analyzed and the reasons they were eliminated from detailed review are described in Section 2.8. In compliance with USACE NEPA regulations (33 CFR, Part 325, Appendix B), one alternative is being evaluated that avoids all impacts to waters of the U.S. Due to the location of waters of the U.S. on the project site, the USACE determined that it is appropriate to analyze a no action alternative that constructs a 247 MW solar facility in a manner that avoids waters of the U.S. and the subsequent need for a Department of the Army permit.

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The applicant signed a large generator interconnection agreement with PG&E for the project in January 2014. This agreement confirms that the project’s electricity output would be deliverable to the transmission grid; it also specifies the interconnection and network facilities that would be required to interconnect the project with the PG&E Moss Landing-Panoche 230 kV transmission line. The applicant executed a power purchase agreement for the project in August 2014. Under this agreement, which is subject to approval by the California Public Utilities Commission, Southern California Edison is obligated to purchase and the applicant is obligated to deliver 247 MWAC of power annually for 20 years beginning in 2019.

The entire project is expected to be fully operational by the end of 2016 and would operate for at least 30 years, with the possibility of a subsequent repowering of the project for additional years of operation. Operations would include monitoring system status, performance, and diagnostics from the control room in the O&M building, along with system production forecasting and scheduling with PG&E and CAISO. The project would operate seven days a week during daylight.

The document outlines various Applicant Proposed Measures (APMs) for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility to mitigate environmental impacts in areas such as aesthetics, agriculture, air quality, and biological resources.

Operational activities would require an estimated 2.84 acre‐feet of water annually, based on the current project layout. Approximately 0.05 acre‐feet (16,000 gallons) would be required for the O&M facilities and fire suppression. Potable water for the O&M facilities would be piped directly from the water well closest to the O&M facility. Sheep/goat watering may require an estimated 0.35 to 0.56 acre-feet per year if there is enough forage to support grazing. During operation of the project, motion-sensor lighting would be used at the O&M building and substation. The lighting would consist of energy-efficient lamps that would be lit only when human activity is detected. Motion sensors would be set to avoid activation by animals. In addition to lighting, security cameras would be installed near the lighting to monitor activity. Constant low-level lighting would be required at the O&M building. This would include a single lamp source near the entrance of the building, which would be activated by a timer. All lighting would include a power switch to conserve energy when the lighting is not required. All lighting would point downward, would be shielded to preserve dark skies, and would adhere to San Benito County’s Lighting Ordinance (19.31.003-009).
The page describes various Applicant Proposed Measures (APMs) for the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project, focusing on biological conservation and protection measures.
Project Description and Alternatives

The document provides a detailed description of the Panoche Valley Solar Facility project, including estimated daily traffic, construction traffic specifications, and the origin and travel distance for workers.
Final EIS
The project involves habitat restoration and revegetation, enhancing corridors for special status species, and ensuring grid reliability through telecommunications upgrades.
The applicant has proposed conservation of 24,618 acres of on-site and adjacent off-site mitigation lands to address the proposed project’s impacts on biological and grazing resources.

Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Project.summary: The project involves the conservation and management of lands within the Panoche Valley. The applicant may purchase conservation easements over 1,500 acres of land as an alternative to the permanent protection of 1,000 acres. These lands are intended to be high-quality habitats for the giant kangaroo rat. The project aims to preserve a total of 25,618 acres of conservation lands in perpetuity.

Organization.name: CDFW
Organization.fullName: California Department of Fish and Wildlife

Organization.name: USFWS
Organization.fullName: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

Project.summary: The project involves the installation of temporary guard structures for overhead crossings of public roadways or existing transmission or distribution lines. Additionally, it includes crossing of 500 kV lines with ADSS fiber optic cable and replacement of wood poles.

PG&E proposes to install new optical ground wire (OPGW) along 17 miles of its existing Panoche-Moss Landing 230 kV transmission line, between the new substation on the project site and the existing PG&E Panoche Substation in Fresno County. The OPGW would replace the existing shield wire in the transmission line, providing telecommunications services between electrical substations and generating facilities or other substations. The project includes minor modifications to substations and requires an SF-299 right-of-way permit from the Bureau of Land Management (BLM).
Project.technology: Optical Ground Wire (OPGW), All-Dielectric Self-Supporting (ADSS) fiber, Power Line Carrier (PLC), leased line systems

Project.summary: PG&E has committed to avoidance and minimization measures during construction for the proposed telecommunication network upgrades.

Under Alternative B, the applicant would construct the proposed Panoche Valley Solar Facility and PG&E would perform primary and secondary telecommunication network upgrades. Measures include proper storage and disposal of waste and hazardous materials, fire season preparedness, and traffic control plan implementation.

PG&E would implement avoidance and minimization measures for sensitive species and their habitat, as required by a state incidental take permit (SITP) approved by the CDFW and the project’s biological opinion issued by the USFWS. PG&E proposes to establish a secondary microwave communication system to meet communications reliability standards. The system includes new microwave towers at the project switching station and Helm Substation.

Project.summary: The multi-span bridges would have abutments near the top of the stream banks and support footings in the ephemeral stream channel. The multi-span bridges would disturb streambed and stream bank habitat during construction from excavation and from concrete foundation installation and equipment.

The OPGW installation would be completed in approximately 12 to 16 weeks; at any one location the construction would take between 2 and 3 weeks. Existing roads and access along the transmission line would be used to install the OPGW, and PG&E would use the same methods when maintaining the electrical system. The locations of the pull/reel sites have been identified through a combination of helicopter and ground surveys and a review of aerial imagery. The criteria used in selecting the final pull/reel sites were accessibility for vehicles, presence of flat or nearly flat land next to existing transmission line route for equipment set-up, existing land use, absence of or minimal habitat for sensitive species, and absence of resources that would restrict work. Preparation of the temporary pull/splice sites would require some minor ground disturbance. Minor structural modifications would also be made to each of the transmission towers to allow splice boxes to be mounted where the sections of OPGW would be spliced (every three to five miles). The pull/reel sites and transmission towers would be accessed generally along existing unimproved roads or improved unsurfaced or surfaced roads that lead to many of the towers; no new roads would be constructed. Helicopters would be used to place materials at the point of installation for towers inaccessible by road. At each of the 75 existing towers along the 17-mile 230 kV transmission line route, minor upgrades to the steel attachments would be required to accommodate installation of the OPGW. These upgrades would include only overhead work on the existing tower, such as replacing the gode peaks with a pulley to accommodate the OPGW. The existing static wire would then be used to pull the new OPGW through each tower pulley. Existing roads or helicopters would be used to provide access to the sites to fashion the attachments needed on each tower. Construction would be completed using a combination of helicopter and ground crews. Helicopters would be used to transport electrical workers to the towers, to deliver materials, and to assist in pulling the OPGW from tower to tower. Approximately four 150-foot by 100-foot landing zones would be constructed approximately every five miles using means similar to pull sites. Establishing these landing zones would involve minimal temporary ground disturbance, and the zones would facilitate the use of helicopters and reduce overall impacts associated with the work. Landing zones would primarily be used for staging materials, picking up and transporting electrical personnel and equipment, and refueling helicopters.

The project aims to provide 247 MW of solar power. Various alternatives, including the CDFW No Fill Alternative and other crossing technologies, were evaluated to reduce impacts on waters of the U.S. while maintaining the project's capacity.

The Westlands CREZ has the potential to accommodate up to 5,000 MW of solar energy generation. The Westlands Water District leases most of the Westlands CREZ to Westside Holdings for commercial development of the 24,000-acre Westlands Solar Park. The park is considering developing PV solar projects that are 200 MW or larger. The project applicant has submitted requests for additional information from Westside Holdings pertaining to the availability of property to construct a solar facility. CAISO information reports indicated that substantial transmission upgrades would not be required to deliver up to 800 MW to the grid. However, it is unknown if a 247 MW solar facility would be able to interconnect to the existing electrical grid. CAISO has approved construction of a new high-voltage Gates-Gregg transmission line, projected to begin operation as early as May 2020 or as late as December 2022.

The Westlands CREZ alternative assumes a 247 MW PV solar facility with project features similar to those described in Section 2.5. The facility would be constructed on an unspecified 2,500-acre site within the Westlands CREZ. The Westlands CREZ alternative also assumes that applicant-proposed measures similar to those described in Table C-1 would likely be applicable to the Westlands CREZ site.

Organization.name: USACE
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: Installation of the multi-span bridges would permanently disturb approximately 0.002 acre within the OHWM of the Las Aguilas Creek and approximately 0.002 acre within the OHWM of Panoche Creek. Placing fill for the two bridges would permanently disturb upland habitat of approximately 1,1402,280 square feet (0.025 acre). The bridge construction would temporarily disturb adjacent upland areas during construction. No waters of the U.S. would need to be filled for electrical cables in the multi-span design because the project would use overhead cables.

The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project involves constructing a 247 MW solar facility. The project site includes critical habitat for the California red-legged frog and is within a 100-foot floodplain. Alternative sites were considered but eliminated due to various constraints, including hydrological features and land availability.

The project involves ford and culvert crossings for jurisdictional ephemeral stream channels (Las Aguilas and Panoche Creeks) and considers alternative off-site locations such as Brownfield-Kettleman City.
Project.technology: Concrete block mattress and multi-barreled concrete box culvert for stream crossings

Project.summary: The Brownfield-Kettleman City site was analyzed as one of several brownfield sites in the project area and was included in the applicant’s 404(b)(1) alternatives information. The site is an active commercial hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility operated by Chemical Waste Management, Inc., and owned by Waste Management, Inc. The site was deemed unsuitable for the construction of a PV solar facility due to its size, potential contamination, and lack of availability for sale or long-term lease. Additionally, the Moss Landing-Panoche site was considered but eliminated from detailed consideration due to its insufficient size and potential environmental impacts.

Organization.name: California Department of Toxic Substances Control
Organization.fullName: California Department of Toxic Substances Control

Organization.name: USFWS
Organization.fullName: United States Fish and Wildlife Service

Project.summary: The Panoche Valley Solar Project aims to construct a 247 MW solar facility in the west-central portion of the Central Valley. Conservation and demand-side management are important but insufficient alone to meet California’s growing energy needs.

The project aims to provide 247 MW of solar power through the construction of a solar facility. Alternative solar technologies and distributed generation were considered but eliminated due to feasibility and project purpose alignment.

Organization.name: United States Army Corps of Engineers
Organization.fullName: United States Army Corps of Engineers

Project.summary: The project involves the construction of a 247 MW solar facility. Alternative forms of renewable energy such as wind, biomass, and geothermal were not considered. Distributed solar generation, which includes rooftop solar and small solar facilities near urban load centers, was evaluated but not selected due to its limitations compared to utility-scale solar.

The Panoche Valley Solar Facility project includes the development of a solar facility with a capacity of 247 MW. The site features hydrological elements such as creeks, drainages, and canals. It also includes jurisdictional wetlands and special status species like the blunt-nosed leopard lizard.
